prop.head.headtext: Confidential Business Information in Historical Context
Policy Reasons for Protection of Confidential Information

head.headtext: Criticism of the Policy of Protecting Information to Ensure the Most Efficient Use of Resources

para.paratext: The recognition of intellectual property is said to encourage the initial creative act. Yet, as Vaver points out:

… in the centuries before copyright and patent laws were established or rigorously enforced, inventive and creative work flourished. And if the British patent law of 1624 really did encourage greater inventiveness, why did the Industrial Revolution take some 150 years more to arrive … In any event, today much creative and inventive work is carried out by employees, who are motivated to work by incentives other than patents or copyrights.[1]

The number of Canadian patents granted to independent inventors, as compared with corporations, fell from 97.3% in 1908 to 36.5% in 1968, and only 5% of all Canadian patents granted went to Canadians. Similar statistics are found in France and Germany.[2]

Furthermore, it must be remembered that there are costs associated with enforcing employment confidentiality contracts and ensuring that the information remains secret. Even in a successful case such as Coca Cola, it is impossible to know whether the cost to the company and its customers in protecting the secret drink formula is greater than the cost of the hidden efforts to copy it. Finally, there is also a cost to society when the advancement of research is obstructed by trade secrecy.

However, this fails to take into account the time lag between changing the laws and the results effected therefrom, the increasingly rapid pace of technological change in the 20th century and the necessity of protecting that new source of wealth, and the differences between the lengthy and costly process of registering a patent as compared with the protection of confidential information.

Part of the costs associated with keeping information secret would be alleviated if the courts articulated more clearly and uniformly what information would be protected and on what terms. Although there is a cost to society where information is kept exclusively in the hands of one party, it must be remembered that intellectual property laws do not prevent copying per se. Copying is prevented only where it is injurious to another or contrary to the public interest. There must be a balance between protecting and disseminating information so that the creation of new inventions will be encouraged while at the same time encouraging the dissemination of information.
D. Vaver, “Intellectual Property Today: Of Myths and Paradoxes” (1990), 69 Can. Bar Rev. 98 at p. 100.

Economic Council of Canada, “Report on Intellectual and Industrial Property” (Ottawa: Information Canada, 1971); D. Vaver, “Intellectual Property Today: Of Myths and Paradoxes” (1990), 69 Can. Bar Rev. 98 at p. 115.
